[[Russian Empire]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|mf=yes|1996|08|23|1915|03|14}} | death_place = [[Tashkent]], [[Uzbekistan]] | resting_place = | occupation = [[Poet]] | language = [[Uzbek language|Uzbek]], [[Russian language|Russian]] | nationality = {{URS}}, {{UZB}} | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | period = | genre = | subject = | movement = [[Socialist Realism]] | notableworks = | spouse = [[Hamid Olimjon]] | partner = | children = | relatives = | influences = | influenced = | awards = [[Hero of Socialist Labor]], 1984; [[Order of Lenin]], 1984 | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''Zulfiya Isroilova''', known by her pen name '''Zulfiya''' (in Cyrillic ''{{lang|uz|Зулфия}}'') (born 14 March 1915 in [[Tashkent]] then part of the [[Russian Empire]] – died 23 August 1996 in Tashkent, [[Uzbekistan]]) was an [[Uzbeks|Uzbek]] writer. ==Early life== Her name Zulfiya originates from the [[Persian language|Persian]] word {{lang|fa|زلف}} ''zulf'' meaning 'a curl of hair' and '(in a mystic sense) the divine mysteries forming the delight of the devotee'.{{cite book|last1=Steingass|first1=F.|authorlink1=Francis Joseph Steingass|title=A Comprehensive Persian-English Dictionary|pages=619–620|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=knA9NptP7xsC&lpg=PA620&ots=9GjXnwj2h3&dq=steingass%20zulf&pg=PA619#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=March 20, 2015}}{{cite web|title=First name: Zulfia|url=http://www.namepedia.org/en/firstname/Zulfia/|website=Namepedia|accessdate=March 20, 2015}} Zulfiya was born in [[Mahallah]] Dergez, near Tashkent to a family of craftsmen. Her parents were very interested in culture and literature. Her mother used to sing her popular songs and tales. ==Career== Her first poem was published 17 July 1931 in the Uzbek newspaper ''Ishchi'' (The Worker). Her first collection of poetry (''Hayot varaqlari'', "Pages of Life") was published in 1932. In the following decades she wrote patriotic works as well as propaganda, pacifist works, and works on nature and women's topics. From 1938 on, Zulfiya worked for various publishers and was a member of several national and interrepublican organizations. She repeatedly was a leader or chief editor for various media. After the death of her husband [[Hamid Olimjon]] in an accident in 1944, she dedicated to him several works. In 1953 she joined the [[Communist Party]] and also became the editor of ''[[Saodat]]'' magazine. In 1956, she was part of a delegation of Soviet writers led by [[Konstantin Simonov]] to the Asian Writers' Conference in [[Delhi]]. In 1957 she participated in the Asian-African Solidarity Conference in [[Cairo]]. ==Personal life== Zulfiya was married to the renowned Uzbek poet [[Hamid Olimjon]]. He died in a car accident on July 3, 1944, in Tashkent. He was 34 years old at the time of his death. ==Death== Zulfiya died at 81 years, on 23 August 1996 in [[Tashkent]]. ==Legacy== In 1999, the Uzbek National Award for Women was created and named after her.{{cite web|url=http://www.lex.uz/pages/GetAct.aspx?lact_id=213818|title=О ПОДДЕРЖКЕ ПРЕДЛОЖЕНИЙ ПО УЧРЕЖДЕНИЮ ГОСУДАРСТВЕННОЙ ПРЕМИИ ИМЕНИ ЗУЛЬФИИ|publisher=lex.uz|accessdate=15 September 2015}} On March 1, 2008, a statue in her memory was unveiled in [[Tashkent]].{{cite web|url=http://news.uzreport.uz/news_9_r_42715.html|title=В Ташкенте открыт памятник Народной поэтессе Узбекистана Зульфие|publisher=uzreport.uz|accessdate=15 September 2015}} ==Awards== * National Poet of [[Uzbek SSR]] (1965) * [[Hero of Socialist Labour (USSR)]] (1984) * [[Order of Lenin]] (1984) * [[USSR State Prize]] in Literature and Art (1976) ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090204141808/http://uzlit.edunet.uz:80/zulfiya.html Biography] (Russian) * [http://youth-health.uz/eng/about_premium_zulfiya/ Information on the Zulfiya prize and Zulfiya]{{dead link|date=July 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zulfiya}} [[Category:1915 births]] [[Category:1996 deaths]] [[Category:People from Tashkent]] [[Category:Uzbekistani women poets]] [[Category:Soviet poets]] [[Category:20th-century Uzbekistani poets]] [[Category:Recipients of the USSR State Prize]] [[Category:Heroes of Socialist Labour]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Lenin]] [[Category:Socialist realism writers]] [[Category:Communist Party of the Soviet Union members]] [[Category:History of Uzbekistan]] [[Category:Pseudonymous writers]] [[Category:Pseudonymous women writers]] [[Category:20th-century women writers]]
